entry.content:
If you’ve arrived at my post angry and pissed off about the title, welcome.  It was sensational, now I hope you stick around to read the rest of my thoughts.  

I have battled my weight throughout my entire human existence.  The battle has been difficult, long, and I usually lose everything but the weight. Let’s face it - when you are writing code, creating a new design, a digital piece of art, or working on your next startup business objectives, you are usually sitting on your ass.  The latest craze is standing desks, but they really do not solve the problem.  The underlying problem is inactivity.  

I put a post up on facebook that created a bit of a stir when I stated that if you are not making fitness a priority in your life alongside your startup, code, and design you are doing it wrong.  I stand by this statement.  I love to eat, and the choices I have made increased the size of my ass past the point that I consider acceptable. This may sound a bit vain, and it is.  While we are busy solving problems or creating the next facebook our bodies are slowly breaking down.  Why are we so bad at seeing this problem before it becomes harder and harder to solve?  Is it something we choose to ignore and hide behind the “geek” cloak?  

Fitness is not hard.  Yes it is far easier if you live in communities like Boulder or Portland, but one could argue you can go for a jog anywhere.  I believe that being fit has to be a top priority.  When you are at your peak, your mind is clear and ready to battle.  I like to think of my brain as a well tooled machine, and the type of fuel I choose can either increase performance or hinder it.  

After two weeks of regular workouts including multiple doubles, I am openly committing to getting back on the fitness horse.  I wasted too much time in NYC getting to where I am today, essentially erasing all of the progress I made in Boulder.  In Portland, I am committing myself once again to the initiative I had in Boulder.  I believe that having a body tuned like Ferrari is not a bad thing.  It is possible, and in fact our duty.  We work hard to create the best software, the best piece of art, why not view our bodies the same way? Why sacrifice ourselves in the process?

I know my hardest challenge is food.  Many of you have the same struggle. I am not talking about GMOs, rather just plain heavy foods.  I grew up in the Midwest, the land of cheeseburgers and sausages and I learned how to eat.  I’m conditioned to eat more than I need in a single meal.  

This message is not meant to convince you. Make your own choice.  Yes, everyone has different circumstances that may make fitness harder or easier, but tell me when fitness has caused a detriment in someone’s life.  Let’s be honest, most people are fat, or overweight in some way.  We have grown to accept this reality to the point where the person of normal weight gets judged like they are abnormal.   What is wrong with us?  Now, I am not Tony Robbins, and I will never claim to be like him.  I state my opinions, and I will tell you to “Fix your shit!”  Not every kid is meant to get a trophy, so I am sorry if I sound tough when I say that it’s our responsibilities to fix our fat asses. No one else’s.  

I am publicly committing to this renewed objective in my life.  I have not forgotten about it.  After spending time in Boulder, where I lived the lightest in my life, I am ready to feel that way again.  It feels great.

At the end of the day, you will make your own decisions.  These decisions will increase your waist line or decrease it.  Do not hide behind the geek cloak. It’s being a geek that makes you overweight, it’s your life choices. So join me and put down that Mt. Dew. 

This photo starts month 1 @ 205lbs.  My goal 165.

entry.title: Since We Made It Here We Can Make It Anywhere
entry.summary: After nearly two years in NYC our time has finally come to an end.  During this time we have been all over the city soaking in everything it has to offer.  As we reflect on our time there, we realize just how much we have accomplished and how thankful...
entry.content:
After nearly two years in NYC our time has finally come to an end.  During this time we have been all over the city soaking in everything it has to offer.  As we reflect on our time there, we realize just how much we have accomplished and how thankful we are to have had the chance to experience it first hand. New York is a fascinating place filled with big dreams, and even bigger egos.  You have to have guts to survive here, and if you have never lived in a major city, amateurs will get eaten alive rapidly.  We were lucky enough to have a corporation move us to try it out and living at 83rd and Columbus on the Upper West Side next to the park definitely made things easier.  Numerous songs have been written about each of the five boroughs, but this is our take on the experiences we shared. 

Let’s start with the food.  With all the cultures of the world blending together it kinda feels like going around the world in Epcot Center, Disney World, but it’s the real deal.  NYC definitely has the most international feel out of any U.S. city we have lived in.  Some of our favorite places include: Cafe Frida {Mexican}, Jacob’s Pickles {American heritage} Tacombi {Mexican}, Russ and Daughters {Jewish Deli}, Katz Deli {Jewish Deli}, Sarabeth’s {American}, The Spotted Big {British Gastropub}, The Breslin {British Gastropub}, Nobu {Japanese}, Quality Meats {Steakhouse}, Korzo Haus {Czech}, and Keste {Neapolitan Pizza}.

When we not getting fat out on the town, we stocked up on ingredients at some of our favorite food purveyors: Dickson’s Farmstand {butcher},  Lucy’s Whey {artisan cheeses}, Jacques Torres Chocolate, The Lobster Pound, Amy’s Bread, and the Union Square Green Market.  Although our kitchen would most likely fit in your bathroom, it was actually quite large for NYC city standards.  We took advantage of our “enormous space” as one of the very few families who actually took the time to cook for ourselves.  

Outside of filling our stomachs, we loved visiting the MOMA, the Met, the Guggenheim, and the Museum of Natural History.  Even though we did not have kids, we loved geeking out on the dinosaur bones.  Getting to eat lunch regularly  on The Highline was relaxing during long summer days.  Watching the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade was a long time childhood dream, and going to the balloon filling party the night before outside our door made it even more special.  We also did a lot of touristy things such as visiting The Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island.  Best of all, dragging Kathryn to see the ball drop on New Years Eve freezing, standing on a pizza box to stay warm was hysterical. She hated every minute up until the last 10 seconds.  

Together, all of these events added up to be a life changing experience that we would not trade for the world.  

By Kathryn...

For me, living and working in the city was a victory lap to conclude a race that I started ten years before. When I graduated from high school, my only objective was to get the hell out of my small town and do something amazing. I took off for New York after I was accepted to New School University, but I wasn’t ready for the path that would be set before me. I returned back to Maine to finish my degree after only three semesters, feeling deflated about my whole experience. When the opportunity arose to return to the city to finish what I started many years ago, I know that I had to give it one more shot.

It’s funny how life will give you what you want, but not all at the same time. When I was 18 years old, I felt entitled to a big cushy job where I could be paid enough to make the city my own, while doing what I love. In my second go around, I got exactly that. This time, I had the privilege of making a life with someone that I love.

New York will always hold a special place in my heart. Chris and I got married here. We got our marriage license at NYC City Hall. I took him to the Metropolitan Opera at Lincoln Center for his birthday. We held hands and went ice skating in Rockefeller Center. We spent Christmas Day walking down 5th avenue and catching the last glimpses of the famous holiday windows. We also spent many hours running around the Central Park loop, dreaming of the life that we were just starting to build together. I’m glad I never achieved my dreams in my first NYC journey. I learned that it’s more fun with someone to share it with. 

By Chris...

If you know me, you know I like to “rant” at times.  I have always believed that being honest doesn’t waste time, however, I have made a promise to myself recently to tailor the message to the desired audience.  With that said, Manhattan was a journey back to a major city for me, it was nothing new.  I grew up in and around Chicago so I knew what to expect, both the good and the bad.  When I left Chicago for Boulder, Colorado I never imagined heading back East ever.  I love my wife and when her work came calling   what was a good man to do? I had to go.  I buckled up and dove in head first selling what I had in Boulder and headed back into the depths of hell I ran so far away from. This time around, however, I learned more about me, and a better understanding of why I left Chicago for Boulder in first place.    

I have come to learn that people like what they like and that even though there are parts of the island that I love, I would rather not listen to John Lock and get off for good. It’s just not for me.  NYC taught me to appreciate nature, more so, than I have ever had before.  People that say oh get on a train and just head North to the mountains have either never lived here or didn’t have a full time job.  I like space, the smell of trees after a morning rain, snow and the people who love it when it falls in buckets, but most importantly peace and quiet.  Silence is impossible in NYC.  No matter what time of day or night there is just noise, everywhere.  NYC has amazing food, just like Chicago, but I loved the farmer’s markets of Boulder, not only how easy and pleasant the experiences there were, but the cost.  They were far  cheaper.  The hardest part of the East for me was being a geek.  Geeks here are second class citizens.  We are not the coolest thing in town, finance and fashion are.  I love my t-shirts, I love flannels and normal everyday clothes but most importantly I value my work more than how I dress.  I have said the East goes out of it’s way to make sure the socioeconomic class system of our country stays in place.  Experiencing this first hand was quite alarming and far worse than Chicago.  I am a capitalist but I believe in helping anyone in business, not just my set of elite friends that I went to Harvard with who all wear the same polo shirt.  Out West there is a sense of community values, where geeks in a coffee shop like Atlas Purveyors could raise their hand with CSS questions and get answers.  Not from google, but from people who actually write code and design everyday.  The Western geeks are not jailed to co-working spaces, private clubs, or meetups that always cost money.  Is NYC technology hot, yes, but I believe you can start a tech startup anywhere nowadays.  Most importantly, if you have a solid product, something worth buying, money will find you.  In Chicago I almost left code to be a trader and I have seen first hand how the markets work, it’s actually a hobby I hope to pursue further one day.  There are always winners and losers in every market and you do not need to live in a certain city to have your business be a winner.  This may all sound like a rant, and yes a tid bit on the negative side, but not all of my time here was like jail.  

Kathryn and I were married here, in Queens actually, something I could have never planned.  NYC taught me to appreciate automation, to be efficient with my time, and to focus on what gives me the best ROI, not only in business, but in life.  The times that Kathryn and I shared here make me smile, especially the art museums.  Since part of Kathryn’s family is from the East I have been lucky enough to travel to Maine.  To eat home made lobster roll sandwiches, to smell the ocean, and smell the salt water smashing the Northeastern coast.  Recently we visited her friend in rural Maine where I had the chance to eat smores, which I hadn’t had since I was a little kid.  Most importantly though, I was able to see the stars.  I believe that too many people have forgotten what stars actually look like, and how small they make you feel.  At the end of the day, NYC has taught me to appreciate the finite amount of time we all have in this world.  Who we chose to spend it with, what we chose to work on, where we chose to visit all take from the fixed pool of minutes we have.  I am thankful for my experiences here, but I more thankful for getting to experience them with the love of my life.

Bye Bye NYC...

The Houghs are leaving Manhattan on the next big adventure of our lives together.  No we are not broadcasting where, and if you know already, consider yourself a member of the VIP Club Hough where the best underground house and techno is played 24/7.  As one of our good friends would like to say “oooh maan, it’s time to partay..” 

Thank you Gotham.

entry.title: Reason Season Lifetime
entry.summary: Recently I have been pondering real value as it relates to startups.  What are startups actually producing?  How long will these technologies last?  I wanted to take one of my favorite quotations and wrap it around topics that we startup geeks and...
entry.content:
Recently I have been pondering real value as it relates to startups.  What are startups actually producing?  How long will these technologies last?  I wanted to take one of my favorite quotations and wrap it around topics that we startup geeks and entrepreneurs would love.  

Every day there are more and more incubators coming online and more and more new startups being released into the wild.  Without sounding too cryptic, I often ask myself what value are many of these companies adding? Do they care?  The companies of our parents and grandparents were built to last for generations. I question how long many of the startup companies today will be around.  

Building a company is tough. It takes more than just words.  I am no longer interested in bragging about what I am working on. I would rather take that time to produce and let my work speak for itself.  I believe in building brands that last the test of time.  The great companies of today were not successes overnight and they lasted generations because they continued to focus on innovation, new products, and a solid brand.  I love technology but I truly detest how short sighted many people are.  If you ask me, wasting my time building a company to flip is no different than flipping condos.  I would rather set out to disrupt an industry and stick with it until all options have been exhausted.  Don’t get me wrong: I am not saying to put all of your eggs in one basket. An average type-A person can have a ton of complex investments running concurrently.  I am saying I prefer to build something of value. 

When I look at a few of my favorite brands outside of technology sector like Dewalt, Berkshire Hathaway, Mercedes, or even Katz Deli in NYC, they have lasted for generations.  They are places were fathers and daughters work together and they have a respected, sought after culture. They are recognized globally, and they provide real value.  

When I work on a product, I ask myself which category I want my company to fall into: Reason, Season, or Lifetime. 

Reason companies are often called “Feature” companies, designed around a single task, or small set of tasks, waiting to get acquired.  They may or may not shoot for hockey stick like growth, but they will not last on their own.  

Season companies come into the markets, disrupt a sector, usually have hockey stick like growth, than either fizzle out or get acquired for a much cheaper valuation.  

Lifetime based companies last the test of time.  They represent a set of products, or entire platform, may or may not have venture capital, and may be publicly traded.  Another key factor in determining where a company falls is just how much impact they will have to the world.  Easier said than done.  

I was once told that how wealthy you are can be determined by the following formula: How long can your family, your children, your children's‘ children and so on live at the same level as you today, without working. I hope to build products and companies that last so that when I kick the bucket, I actually accomplished something. 

If you’re building a technology company, build a strong foundation.  Focus on your vision, your product, where you are going, and ignore the fucking scenesters.  Build a strong advisory board of close friends, not just people who hang on you.  You will work a good portion of your life so make sure it happens in the location you want it to, not where someone else or incubator tells you to.  Money will flow to where it’s replicated the easiest, and even in these markets many of my Chicago trader friends are killing it for this exact reason.  You can get capital outside of the valley or NYC if just work your ass off.  Most of what I have said isn’t news, it’s a conversation I have been having in my head.  It’s my beliefs on business on paper.

Am I being too traditional with my thinking? Is this just not possible in technology?

One of my favorite sayings from an unknown author:

People come into your life for a REASON, a SEASON or a LIFETIME.

When you know which one it is, you will know what to do for that person.  When someone is in your life for a REASON, it is usually to meet a need you have expressed. They have come to assist you through a difficulty, to provide you with guidance and support, to aid you physically, emotionally or spiritually. They may seem like a godsend and they are.  They are there for the reason you need them to be. Then, without any wrongdoing on anyone's part or at an inconvenient time, this person or you will say or do something to bring the relationship to an end. Sometimes they die. Sometimes they walk away. Sometimes they act up and force you to take a stand.  What we must realize is that our need has been met, our desire fulfilled, their work is done. The prayer you sent up has been answered and now it is time to move on.

Some people come into your life for a SEASON, because your turn has come to share, grow or learn. They bring you an experience of peace or make youlaugh. They may teach you something you have never done. They usually give you an unbelievable amount of joy. Believe it, it is real. Yet only for a season.  

LIFETIME relationships teach you lifetime lessons, things you must build upon in order to have a solid emotional foundation. Your job is to accept the lesson, love the person and put what you have learned to use in all other relationships and areas of your life.  Lifetime relationships can run continuously, or for many, on again, off again.  Your job is to also accept that life may have its ebbs and flows, but time and distance apart does not have to define a relationship.

Unknown

entry.title: Hough Fat Kid Burgers
entry.summary: If you’re looking for an outstanding “FAT KID” burger recipe this summer, look no further. I was hesitant to share this family secret but I am curious as to what others could do building off of it.  This recipe makes close to 20 1lb burgers depending...
entry.content:
If you’re looking for an outstanding “FAT KID” burger recipe this summer, look no further. I was hesitant to share this family secret but I am curious as to what others could do building off of it.  This recipe makes close to 20 1lb burgers depending on how big you make each one.  

  • 7 lbs of 85% lean burger meat.  Trust me you need the fat, do not get the extra lean kind.
  • 4 spicy italian pork sausages. 
  • 3 diced jalapeños.
  • 1 diced red onion.
  • 3/4 stick of Irish Gold garlic herb butter.
  • Plenty of garlic powder, and if you have fresh cut cloves toss them in too.
  • A few pinches of sea salt.
  • Plenty of ground pepper.
  • 4 free range eggs.
  • Shredded jalapeño jack cheese, the more the merrier.  
  • 20oz can of Guinness. 

Mix all of that together until it’s a consistent near solid sticky bowl of meat, than start making patties.  Each of the burgers weighs in around 1lb or around the size of a fist. Lay each patty on a cookie sheet covered with tin foil and cover each of them with a thin layer of italian bread crumbs. Now you’re ready for the grill.  Depending on how well you like your burgers cooked, I usually keep them on the grill for a total of 6-8 minutes, flipping them for 3-4 minutes on each side.  Add 2 additional slices of jalapeño jack cheese on the second flip to kick it up a notch.   

Pairs well with Guinness!  

Hope you enjoy this recipe! If you take a stab at it or modify it, let me know how it goes.

entry.title: Every Kid Gets A Trophy
entry.summary: I have been working as a code monkey ever since I left college.  I learn visually but can handle straight text when I need to, and I would like to think that I am not design inept. A hefty goal of mine this year is to work hard to master Ruby and the...
entry.content:
I have been working as a code monkey ever since I left college.  I learn visually but can handle straight text when I need to, and I would like to think that I am not design inept. A hefty goal of mine this year is to work hard to master Ruby and the Ruby on Rails framework.  My traditional experience told me to find a class first, however, after listening to numerous recommendations from This Week in Startups and This Week in Web Design I started out online. 

For this experiment I pretended to start from scratch as though I had no prior programming or design experience.  I knew I would tackle more than just Ruby classes, but I wanted to experience all of it first hand. I started with Code School, Treehouse, and Code School. I know there are quite a few out there but I feel these three cover a good number of core competencies. Or, at least they claim to. I also wanted to test the theory I have been hearing others say that “college is just not required anymore.”  I started this experiment at the first of the year, with the initial hypothesis that “college is necessary for coding and design.”  Let me break down each of the three online options I used. 

Codecademy is the cheapest of the three. It’s free. It also has the most functional design.  Some users may be turned off by this, the same way they would be opening a math book.  It’s primary focus is javascript, but they recently started offering some css and html courses.  Being a coder, I enjoyed the code samples and the logical progression through the course.  There wasn’t any fluff. No videos.  No music.  Just code.  If you are setting out to learn javascript and jquery I would advise you to take every course available here first.  You will learn javascript, not every piece of it, but you will get a solid base. 

Treehouse definitely has the most “fluff” out of the three and by far the most content, however, it is also the most expensive.  If you are truly new to technology you will enjoy the videos, music, and multiple choice tests.  The lack of true coding examples and tests keeps me from recommending it ahead of Code School.  Overall I would say Treehouse would be best for designers transitioning into coding, but it will not in it’s current state give you all of the necessary tools to complete that transition. You will need the other two for sure.  In terms of the design basics like layout or color theory I thought the topics were thoroughly covered.  

Code School won me over completely the moment I opened the “Try Ruby” course.  The site has an excellent blend between videos, music, and writing code.  While it does not have as much content as Treehouse, I have to say that Code School takes a more in depth approach to learning.  Outside of their courses they also have hours of video content available on a variety of subjects.  If you ask me, if you are brand new, start with Codecademy & Code School.  

I would like to think that learning online has come a long way. Sadly, I have to say it still has a way to go before it can replace classroom learning for technical subjects completely.  Yes, you learn the basics. However online learning will not give you that in depth perspective, and definitely not the community aspect of working along side your peers in the same room.  

At the end of the day I ended up signing up for a course at NYU on Ruby on Rails and I am glad I did.  By combining the online courses from Code School and the traditional experience in the class room I feel will be able to start building things in Ruby after the course.  No, I will not be a pro by any means, but I have the tools to start,  and have networked with fellow mentors to keep the learning process going.  Networking is not the only area where online learning breaks down.

The biggest problem with online learning is this: every person gets a trophy or a badge, and no one can get a failing grade.

The Treehouse tests were beyond easy to game, and no matter how many times you failed a question you can just keep guessing until you passed. Codecademy & Code School handled this best by making the user submit code examples to progress to the next session, however, you still have access to google and Stack Overflow to cheat your way through.  Let’s not pretend people do not cheat.  In order for learning to be effective there has to be failing grades, markers to force people to start over.  The carrots or badges are great, but what do they truly represent?

Would you hire someone based on the number of badges they have?

I keep hearing people questioning if college is necessary, and backing up those claims with sites like these, or the fact they are already running a startup with only their high school diploma.  Still, college degrees are still valid and in many cases required.  That’s not to say that there are not winning lottery tickets out there who have success, it’s not the norm.  This is not an attack on them at all.  I am happy it worked out for them.  To me, it’s like taking all of your savings and buying lottery tickets with it.  

School teaches more than coding, it teaches interpersonal skills, communication, time management, and how to interact with others to name a few.  My wife and I plan on having a family soon and schooling, especially the type of schooling, is a top most priority.  I am often asked what about college as I am the only programmer in my immediate family.  Here is where a good blend of reasoning comes in.  Does it make sense to buy the lotto ticket and avoid college all together? No.  It also does not make sense to stay 100% in the classroom with no real world experience.  In my opinion you need a blend.  I would advise our children to complete college over the course of 4-6 years blended with coding, online learning, and working at startups full time.  People need to know how to talk, how to interact with others, especially members of the opposite sex in the workplace.  They need to learn just how bad the “brogramming” experience really is and why they shouldn’t recreate it.  Having a broad scope of knowledge across a variety of technical and non-technical subjects helps prevent creating a horse in central park with blinders on.  It also, helps them be a better leader and less likely to be taken advantage of by others.  

Call me crazy, but school still wins my vote.  Until the online sites actually give failing grades and better report card like metrics, they are not going to replace the classroom experience completely.  Instead of thinking every kid gets a trophy, maybe we should consider the fact that we are all different.  Not everyone will be a coder or designer, just like not everyone can play sports.  If you or a child is horrible at baseball, try basketball, try football, or do whatever you feel you can do best.  If you’re are always awarded trophies and badges you will not know what you are actually proficient at.

entry.title: 2012 Goals

entry.content:
Instead of the plain old yearly goals that everyone outlines for the future, every new year, I started thinking about themes and what means the most to me in 2012.  What can I change now, starting now, today.  I have come to understand and accept my past, learn from it, grow from it, but not let it hold me back.  I am not afraid to tell others what I feel, even if it's not what they want to hear.  I have grown to accept the fact that pleasing everyone is truly impossible, and being a chameleon is b.s.   When you set out to start a company, sail a ship, buy a one way ticket you have to have a set of parameters to guide you, yet, not restrict you so much there are no alternatives.  Since I have left Chicago, life has been a roller coaster to say the least.  There have been ups and downs, but I still do not regret taking my first steps on the path away from where I grew up.  The nervousness has since subsided, but the excitement hasn't.  The friends I have met on my journey outside of Chicago have quickly become part of the chosen family I hope to have forever, and the plans I have made with the love of my life Kathryn warm my heart.  So what's next? I think of this all the time.  Yes, there are many things brewing in the kitchen - have to say this for our stalkers.  But focusing on themes, I have locked in three for me:Think, Create, Act. Yes, they are a little broad, but after quite a few sessions on the treadmill I was able to narrow down my focus to these three.

Think

This year I want to dive deeper into Buddhism, learn more about the spiritual journey, it's a piece of me that I have grown to appreciate the more I dive in.  Directly related to this spiritual initiative is what I call being more "zen" or the "water flowing through rocks."  Working and living in a major city like Chicago or Manhattan, comes with stress, plain and simple. If you have ever lived in a major city, you know what I am referring to.  No, I am not going into the rants now, I will save them for later, but they are easy to list.  While you can not control others, you have full control over your reactions to others' behaviors or lack there of.  I have come to learn and actively practice not letting much get to me.  Life is just too short to be stressed right?  If you follow me on twitter, you just read this and was like "yeah right" but acknowledge this, there is a big difference between rants {tweets} and the movements you make every day in life just walking down the street, holding the door for your elderly neighbor, and helping a child get a drink off the coffee shop counter.

Create

I enjoy working in coldfusion, but to be honest. I am creative.  I have started learning Ruby and Rails this year and have been focusing more on UIE.  As my wife has taken the leap into learning how to code, I will be spending time  on a journey I call back to the basics.  I am planning on going through the same set of Treehouse tasks she has been going through.  I figure a solid refresher, no matter how long you have been coding can't hurt.  Plus, there are always things that you have been doing, sometimes for years, incorrectly in terms of coding architecture and principles.  I want to write more in 2012, not for you, but for me.  While I would welcome an audience to read my craziness, I want to be open with myself, be authentic, and put it out there on paper.  Don't care if I get signed for a book.  It's for me. Enjoy.

Act

I have made a commitment to kill off my fat stomach.  No, I do not have body image issues, but health and fitness are huge priorities in my life.  I like being tone, fit, and that means it has to go.  Luckily we live a very holistic lifestyle and are probably one of the only families who actually cook at home in Manhattan.  While I may never get a 6 pack, shedding about ten pounds would make me very happy.  Being married to a personal trainer has it's perks and have already put on a significant amount of muscle mass breaking through markers on squats, shoulder presses, and even simple things like dips.  Yet, being the type-a person I am, I have quite a ways to go.

I will expand on these as make my way through this year, and to be honest with you, this year's plans already make me beyond excited.  What do you think? Think I am crazy?  I hope you do.  Keep on fighting, keep on learning, keep on kicking ass and taking names.

entry.title: I Run 4 The Fuck Yous & Fuck Yeahs!
entry.summary: What do you think of when you run? When you’re busting your ass at the gym? Is it only about losing weight or something more?  My journey to health started a few years ago when I landed in Colorado.  I used to weigh over 200lbs! Yes, I know.  Fat ass...
entry.content:
What do you think of when you run? When you’re busting your ass at the gym? Is it only about losing weight or something more?  My journey to health started a few years ago when I landed in Colorado.  I used to weigh over 200lbs! Yes, I know.  Fat ass! Seriously though, it was pretty disgusting, and if you ever visit Colorado, you’ll learn quickly why it’s known as the healthiest state in the U.S.

When I met my wife she encouraged me to start training, working out for more than just weight loss, and instead focusing on events.  Not competing to win, but running to be part of the small percentage of like minded bad asses that swim, bike, run for fun.  The same drive and determination to succeed in life easily applies to racing, to exercise, to anything for that matter.  After deep periods of reflection in my life I came to discover that I always did everything, every sport, every task, whatever 110%.  That means if you sat a bottle of Kettle One in front of me, consider it gone. Type-A people don’t fuck around, they don’t waste time.  They need a mission, a goal to hook on to, to run with, to put that high paced energy into.  Often, they choose poorly.  I chose to be an athlete.

When I first started running, I used to picture all of the people, places, events that pissed me off.  You know the ones right?  I pictured them as though I was there, tasting the air, feeling the emotions rushing through my veins. In my mind, I was punching that person in the face, standing up in front of haters and screaming fuck you, driving that ferrari 360 modena top down at 150mph.  Working out angry solved a problem. It seemed to fill a void.  The rush of adrenaline helped kill off the old feelings, the baggage I had been carrying.

As an athlete you can either work out angry or happy.  I only knew how to run for the fuck yous.  More and more time went by, and I shaved more and more time off my current mile pace as well as built a good amount of new muscle mass, yet, something was missing.  I was losing energy.  The anger wasn’t there anymore.  One day running on the treadmill my ipod started blasting “I Remember”, by Kaskade.

I felt a new rush come over me that I had never felt before.  It was pure happiness.  I wasn’t mad anymore.  This newfound energy rushed through my veins even more powerful than when I was angry. I felt lighter, less burdened, and the thoughts rushing through my mind were happy, thankful, filled with joy.  I started running for the fuck yeahs.

The people, the events, the experiences I am grateful for in life.  The times I cried out of joy, the plans I have for the future, the focus I have in my journey of enlightenment.  Living.  I know nothing is perfect in life, but what I have learned so far, is that being negative, carrying anger, being mad, just wastes time.  It brings negative energy into your life and the lives of those around you.  Yes, running angry for me served a purpose, a means to purge myself of older lingering feelings, to get rid of fear, to make room for the holes to be filled with light.  If you’re working out angry, be conscious of these feelings, let them pass, and work towards working out happy.  Be yourself, and let these feelings go, move on to better things.

Today is Monday, October 24th 2011, and this is my first ever blog post.  If you do not like what I have to say, so be it.  Go somewhere else.  I don’t care if you like it or not, my writing is not for everyone.  If you care to share what inspires you to run, I would love to find out.  I hope we can inspire each other.

It could be argued that finding your business partner is no different than being lucky enough to find the right person for you. I can not begin to share with you, just how many failures I have had at this game, but this time I got it right. In the startup of life I have made one of the best decisions I ever could have made.

A letter to our families:

Dear Family and Friends,

Finding your soulmate in this world is quite a challenge. It’s something that takes time and lots of searching. It also takes a great understanding of who you are, what you want in another person, and where you want to go in this world. The search comes not without diversions and challenges, but in the end, it is one of the most amazing things you can do in this life.

Chris and Kate are very excited to announce a very happy surprise. We decided to get married! We have been talking about getting married for quite sometime, and we decided not to wait. We met on February 8, 2010 in Boulder, CO, and we were married on February 5, 2011 in Queens, NY.

The whole event was very New York and we did it just like you would expect. Kate is low maintenance (the opposite of a bridezilla) – shebought her wedding dress from Macy’s in Herald Square. We also had our rings handcrafted by an artisan from Massachusetts. We had cakefrom Magnolia Bakery, one of the most famous bakeries in the city! For the ceremony, we were accompanied by a non-denominational pastorand a witness –that’s it! We are very excited that our lives have brought us together in NYC and we hope to enjoy a few exciting years together as newlyweds before were expand our family.

We are lucky to have you all as supportive friends and family in just about every time zone. Because of this, we are going to celebrate our marriage with you all next year, for our first wedding anniversary. We’re planning on making a few stops across the country to celebrate this good news.

We will be sending announcements to our close friends and family in the coming weeks with more info and pictures.

Lots of love

Chris and Kate Hough

Not a day goes by when I am not thankful for have meeting KathrynHough. I love you baby.
